sub_topic: Time dilation in a moving frame of reference
message_1: A spaceship travels from Earth to a nearby star at a speed of 0.8c (where c is the speed of light). According to special relativity theory, how much time would have passed on the spaceship’s clock compared to the time passed on Earth during the trip?
message_2:
To determine the time dilation experienced by the spaceship traveling at 0.8c, we can use the time dilation formula from special relativity:

Δt' = Δt / √(1 - v²/c²)

where Δt' is the time experienced by the spaceship, Δt is the time experienced on Earth, v is the spaceship's velocity (0.8c), and c is the speed of light.

Plugging in the values:

Δt' = Δt / √(1 - (0.8c)²/c²)

Δt' = Δt / √(1 - 0.64)

Δt' = Δt / √(0.36)

Δt' = Δt / 0.6

So, the time experienced by the spaceship (Δt') is equal to the time experienced on Earth (Δt) divided by 0.6. This means that the spaceship's clock will show a shorter time compared to the time passed on Earth during the trip. For example, if 10 years passed on Earth, the spaceship's clock would show 10 / 0.6 = 16.67 years.
